blocks.text: Data classification assigns labels to information based on sensitivity and handling requirements. These labels guide how data should be stored, transmitted, and accessed.
Common classification levels include public, internal, confidential, and restricted. Public data can be freely shared, while restricted data requires strict controls.
Classification allows organizations to apply proportional protection. Highly sensitive data receives stronger encryption, monitoring, and access restrictions than low-risk information.
Automated classification tools analyze content and metadata to identify sensitive data at scale. Manual labeling alone cannot keep up with enterprise data volumes.
Classification also supports compliance and auditing. Policies can enforce encryption and retention rules based on classification labels.

For classification to be effective, employees must understand labeling requirements and systems must enforce handling rules automatically. Security architecture integrates classification into storage, collaboration, and data transfer systems.
